Triggering Event: He watched from behind the counter as his ex-wife's new husband, half his age, carried their bags out of the store. Their laughter echoed like a slap in his face. He couldn't help but compare the man's youthful vigor to his own aching joints. As they left, she turned and caught his eye, smiling smugly before following her toy boy out into the sun. His grip tightened on the counter, knuckles white with suppressed rage.
Generated Assessment: He was so hurt when he saw her smiling at that young man, it made him feel like he had been punched in the gut again. The way he stood tall, shoulders back, with confidence and ease, just made it worse. It seemed like he didn’t even notice how awkward it must have looked for her to be so happy about leaving him. She probably thought she could just move on and find someone younger and better than him. I don't blame her; after all, who wouldn't want someone younger and more energetic? But still, it felt like a slap in the face. That’s why he couldn’t bear to look at her anymore. Every time he glanced over, he imagined what she might be thinking - perhaps she was already planning their wedding or simply enjoying the thrill of being with someone who could keep up with her. Maybe she thought he was too old and tired, too worn out by life, and she wanted someone fresh and vibrant. It wasn’t fair, but he couldn’t shake off the feeling of being replaced, of being left behind. Even though he knew it wasn’t rational, he kept replaying those moments, letting himself get lost in his negative thoughts. And now, every time he sees her, it feels like she’s laughing at him, which makes him even angrier. He doesn’t know if he can handle this much pain, especially when it feels like everyone around him is moving on smoothly. They’re all getting married, having babies, building

Triggering Event: He found an old essay, unsigned but unmistakably his student's work, in which she wrote about her struggles at home. He'd never noticed her quiet demeanor was a cry for help.
Generated Assessment: He must have been oblivious to it until now. The fact that he didn't notice her quiet demeanor before is simply too ridiculous to comprehend. It's as if he had a mental filter that prevented him from seeing anything beyond what he wanted to see. It's almost laughable that he went through all this time with no idea what was going on behind closed doors. She must have been doing an incredible job of hiding it, which makes me even more confused. I'm starting to wonder if there was something else going on entirely that he missed. This is getting weird. If he didn't know, then how did she manage to keep it under wraps? It's like she was a master of deception or something. He might as well be saying he knew nothing about her life. That's so unbelievable. What kind of teacher does that? It's just too much to believe. He could've easily picked up on it if he looked hard enough. This whole thing feels like a conspiracy. There are so many questions swirling around in my head. How did she manage such a feat? Was there really nothing he saw? Or was he just not paying attention? Is this guy for real? He acted like everything was fine when we were talking about her last week, and he has no clue. What kind of teacher doesn't notice these things? They're supposed to be looking out for students' well-being. That's insane. She must have done some serious damage control to keep him from noticing.

Triggering Event: She returned home from another late night at the restaurant, exhausted and craving silence. As she stepped into her apartment, the emptiness was palpable. No warm greeting from a pet, no hum of a partner making dinner in the kitchen. Just the echo of her own footsteps. She noticed the plants she'd bought herself were wilting, thirsty for attention she hadn't given them in days. She felt a pang of neglect - not just from others, but from herself too.

It's like she doesn't realize that every time she does something like this, I feel like I'm being ignored again. But honestly, it's not about that. I think what really bothers me is how she doesn't seem to care about the state of our apartment. It's always messy when she comes home, and I'm starting to feel like I'm doing all the cleaning up by myself. I've been putting off telling her because I don't want to start a fight, but it feels like an open secret anyway. We never talk about it, and she just leaves her things scattered around. And then there are times when she's just leaving everything as is—books on the floor, dirty dishes piled high—and expecting me to deal with it. Triggering Event: Every Saturday, like clockwork, he'd head to the park with her old favorite book in his bag. Today, as he sat down under their tree, a gust of wind blew a page free, revealing a small, dried flower pressed between them. A bittersweet smile flickered on his face before grief surged again, fresh and overwhelming.

Triggering Event: A young resident, barely out of medical school, corrects her in front of the entire surgical team during morning rounds, "No, Dr. W., that's not how we do it here." The room falls silent as she feels a flush of embarrassment creep up her neck.
Generated Assessment: A recent incident where I felt belittled by my peers has left me questioning my self-worth. During a presentation, one of my colleagues criticized my approach, saying, "You're not doing what we do here," which seemed to be a veiled jab. When asked if they had attended the same conference, they replied with a smirk, "Oh no, but I know exactly what you did wrong." Their comment was laced with an air of superiority, leaving me feeling inadequate. It's as if they were implying that my actions didn't align with the expected standards of our organization, making me wonder if I'm truly capable of meeting these expectations.

Triggering Event: He returned home to an empty apartment after another day of muted silence from his students. The only sound was the ticking clock, each second echoing like a mockery of time passing without her. A lone photograph on the mantel caught his eye - them laughing on a beach, before cancer stole her smile and left him alone with despair.
Generated Assessment: He often wondered what would have been if she were still there. Would they be cooking dinner together now, reminiscing about how it used to be? Or maybe they'd just sit down to read a book, enjoying the quiet comfort of each other's company. It seemed so far away, yet he couldn't help but imagine those moments. What if they had found a way to beat cancer? Maybe life wouldn't have turned out this way, and he could have grown old beside her, watching sunsets together. But then again, what if she hadn’t gotten sick in the first place? They might’ve never met, and he wouldn’t know her. No one knew what could have been, but it’s hard not to wish for that alternate path. Life is full of what-ifs—each one leading to a different reality, some good, others bad. Yet, here he sits, lost in thoughts of what could have been.

Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, standing behind the cash register at his local retail store, grits his teeth as a customer snaps their fingers impatiently, commenting, "Is this your first day? Hurry up!" He feels his face flush with anger but maintains a stoic expression, focusing on scanning the next item without acknowledging the remark.
Generated Assessment: Yeah, I'm pretty sure he thinks I don't know what's going on, like I'm just some dumb kid who can't even handle basic retail tasks. He probably wonders if I'll ever get the hang of it, if I'll be stuck working here forever. Maybe he thinks I'm so clueless that I'll never learn how to run the register efficiently—like I have no idea how to use the scanner or process payments correctly. It makes me think he thinks I'm either an idiot or just really incompetent.

Triggering Event: He flipped through the pages of her sketchbook, stopping at a charcoal drawing of him. But it wasn't his face that caught his eye; it was the inscription below: "With L." He felt a pang in his chest, jealousy gnawing at him like never before.

Well, let me tell you something, sweetheart - nobody cares about your looks. Nobody gives a shit about what you're drawing. They don't care if you're talented or not. They don't care if you're trying to express yourself. All they care about is what's inside your head. And from where I'm standing, there's nothing but garbage coming out of it. You know why I'm upset? It's because you're making me feel like a complete fucking idiot. Like all this time, I've been thinking about you, wondering when we might finally get together, and then I see this...this fucking piece of art that tells me everything I need to know right there. Maybe you just wanted to play a little game, to see how long I'd wait

Triggering Event: She returned home from her shift at the hospital to find a trash bag full of dead roses blocking her doorway, remnants of yesterday's storm scattering their petals like bloodstains across the worn-out welcome mat she'd shared with her late husband. A note pinned to the bag read, "You're wasting your life on the living when you should be tending to your own dead." Her knuckles turned white as she crushed the paper in her fist, rage surging through her veins like a fever. She hurled the bag into the street, the sound of shattering glass echoing from within - his favorite vase, no doubt.
Generated Assessment: Fuck this shit! It’s just so fucking personal. I mean, who does that? Who would do such a thing?! They think they can get under my skin by leaving me a bunch of dead flowers?! Like, what the fuck is wrong with these people?! And don’t even get me started on that vase. That was his favorite vase, and now it’s shattered all over the sidewalk. Does anyone actually believe that they did this just because they wanted to piss me off? Or are they just trying to make me feel guilty about living my life? It’s all so damn petty. You know what? This isn’t about me. This isn’t about how much I’ve changed since he died. No, it’s all about them. They’re the ones who are really messed up here. They must have some kind of problem that makes them think they can just leave me messages like that. But for now, let’s just say I won’t be giving those fuckers any joy. Not today, at least. Fuck you, whoever you are. Triggering Event: He paused, knife hovering over the butternut squash, in his quiet kitchen. The sunlight filtering through the window caught the edge of the cutting board where she used to sit, peeling potatoes with her weathered hands. A lone tear dropped onto the squash, merging with the moisture already there. He wiped it away, his heart echoing with an emptiness that even his culinary arts couldn't fill today.
Generated Assessment: Fuck, this is so unfair! I'm trying to cook dinner for my family while he's out running errands. My life isn't as perfect as his, but does that mean I have to suffer? Does he have no idea how hard it is to keep everything together around here? How about the time he went out and came back with a new fucking blender? Who buys a blender just because they're bored with their old one? And now he's complaining that we don't eat fresh enough? What about when he was out working two jobs to pay off student loans? You know what? Maybe if you were as busy as me, you'd be grateful for every little thing. But fuck no, you get to enjoy your precious squash and your perfect kitchen. At least I can say I made the soup from scratch today instead of relying on some pre-made crap like you did last week. You think cooking up some bland chicken breasts makes you special? Please, I've been making those same chicken breasts all week. You can't just assume that being busy means I'm doing shit, especially since I'm juggling work and taking care of our 2-year-old on top of it. So go ahead and judge, but at least I'm not stuck in a rut, waiting for him to come home and take care of things, unlike some people I could mention.
